texts.shortText: Medium-sized kingfisher with black crest on head, eyes black, bill long, black and dagger-like. Dorsal parts black with white markings. Neck and chest white with broad black collar almost broken in centre. Male has a second much narrower black band below, but this absent in female. Legs and feet black.

Global: Across Africa, Middle East and Asia, except driest parts. Five regional subspecies recognised.

Local/Regional: Across the wetter eastern and southern regions of South Africa, mostly associated with inland waters, but also along the coast.

Common resident and one of the three most common kingfishers in the world. Found on almost any inland water body with small fish, less abundant in fast-flowing streams and mountainous areas. Also common along seashores.

Usually seen singly or in pairs, but roosts communally at night. Perches conspicuously, often raising and lowering the tail. Frequently hovers with body held almost vertical and head forward. Also bathed by making several rapid shallow dives, then preening vigorously. Prey are battered to death before being swallowed head first.
Feeds mainly on small fish, but also takes crustaceans and large insects.

Nests in holes excavated by both sexes in vertical sand or mud banks adjacent to water. The nest hole takes an average of 27 days to dig and is about 6 cm in diameter and 80-240 cm long, ending in an unlined chamber.  

Peak laying dates August – November, usually laying 4-6 almost spherical, glossy white eggs. Incubation time about 18 days and young remain in the nest for about 24-29 days.  Unusual in that they are often co-operative breeders with young birds from previous broods assisting the parents, or even unrelated adults, to raise their young. Number of helpers increases in sites with poor food supply.
Very distinctive and unlikely to be confused with any other species.
Hockey, PAR, Dean, WRJ & Ryan, PG (2005). Robert’s Birds of Southern Africa (7th edition). The Trustees of the John Voelckler Book Fund, Cape Town. (p. 184).
